componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Vornado Realty Trust Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Call. My name is Christine, and I will be your operator for today's call. This call is being recorded for replay purposes. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Ms. Cathy Creswell, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to Vornado Realty Trust Third Quarter Earnings Call. Yesterday afternoon, we issued our third quarter earnings release and filed our Form 10-Q with the Securities and Exchange Commission. These documents, as well as our supplemental fin
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to Vornado Realty Trust Third Quarter Earnings Call. Yesterday afternoon, we issued our third quarter earnings release and filed our Form 10-Q with the Securities and Exchange Commission. These documents, as well as our supplemental financial information package, are available on our website, www.vno.com, under the Investor Relations section. In these documents and during today’s call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliation of these measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in our earnings release, Form 10-Q and financial supplements. 
Please be aware that statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements and actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. 
Please refer to our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K for more information regarding these risks and uncertainties. The call may include time sensitive information that may be accurate only as of today’s date. The Company does not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements.
On the call today from management for our opening comments are: Michael Fascitelli, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Greenbaum, President of the New York Division; Mitchell Schear, President of the D.C. Division; and Joseph Macnow, Chief Financial Officer. 
In addition, Steven Roth, Chairman of the Board, will be present for the duration of the call. I will now turn the call over to Michael Fascitelli.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cathy. Good morning, and welcome to our Third Quarter Earnings Call. We are happy you are all be joining us today and appreciate your time and attention. After my opening remarks, David Greenbaum will talk about our New York business, and Mitchell
componenttext:
Thanks, Cathy. Good morning, and welcome to our Third Quarter Earnings Call. We are happy you are all be joining us today and appreciate your time and attention. After my opening remarks, David Greenbaum will talk about our New York business, and Mitchell Schear will talk about our Wasghington business, followed by Joe Macnow, who will provide a financial overview of the quarter and then we'll answer your questions. We'll end at 11:00.
Before getting started, I would like to acknowledge the devastation the Northeast suffered from Hurricane Sandy. This tragedy, which cost over 100 lives thus far, and tens of billions of property damage, affected our home bases in New York and Washington, particularly New York, which was hardest. 
I'm pleased to report that we suffered no personal injuries and only minor property damage. I want to thank all of our people for the incredible job they did and express our best wishes to all those affected by the hurricane as they recover. 
David and Mitchell will comment further, particularly David, on the the specifics for their businesses. 
Overall, I'm quite satisfied with our third quarter results, which were better than last year's third quarter. In spite of the downward pressure coming from Washington D.C. and no story. It's interesting to note that if Washington would have been leveled this year to last, we would have had comparable FFO performance over the prior year's quarter of 7%. 
The Washington office market is sluggish, and the New York office market lacking support from the financial service industry is locked in neutral. However, it is clear from our financial results that our New York portfolio is outperforming the market, and our Washington portfolio is outperforming the projections we provided in our public filings. David and Mitchell will expand on this in a few minutes. Let me update you on asset sales. Part of our program to simplify and to recycle capital into our core portfolio, high-quality office and retail assets. 
In the third quarter, we closed on the previously announced sales of the Washington Design Center, Washington Office Center, the Canadian Tradeshow Business in Dorchester, a non-core strip shopping centers. Total proceeds from these sales were $323 million, with a  third quarter net gain of $149 million. 
Importantly, in the fourth quarter, we announced the sale of 2 mall for $1.25 million, the Green acres Mall and Alexander's King Plaza Mall, which were both sold to the Macy's company. When completed, these transactions will produce substantial proceeds and gains, and Joe will provide further detail in a few minutes on the specifics of these gains and distributions. 
We also announced the sale of a 3-building suburban office complex in Fairfax County, Virginia for $126 million, resulting in a net gain of $35 million. We sold the building on Marcus Street in Philadelphia, which is part of the gallery for $60 million, resulting in a gain of $35 million. We expect to close both these deals in the fourth quarter. 
In addition, we expect to close the fourth quarter with the previously announced sale of the Boston Design Center, which is approximately $72 million. 
Lastly, we sold our equity investment to Brookfield Asset Management for $28 million. We will continue to hold $25 million of 4.75% 2018 debentures. 
In summary, this year, we produced $2.3 billion of assets sales with a net gain of $674 million and expect to pay at least a special long-term capital gains dividend of $202 million or $1.02 per share for a share of Kings Plaza. 
We intend to do a tax-deferred lifetime exchange with the sale proceeds of Greenacres and others. We will continue to dispose of noncore assets. We just acquired a 25% participation in a $475 million first mortgage and mezzanine loans on 7107 Avenue, a retail redevelopment property in Times Square, where we already have 2 properties in that market. 
The yield today is 11%, which will increase our senior position. We will continue to invest in our existing assets and development opportunities. Given the current environment, our strategy for acquisition will be measured and focused on continuing to expand our leading New York City street retail platform and upgrading our high-quality office property platform. 
Let me now turn the call over to David to discuss the New York business.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael, and good morning to all. Before I turn to the results for the quarter, I do want to spend a minute talking about what we've been going through here in New York City over the past several days. We have contingency plans for almost all o
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael, and good morning to all. Before I turn to the results for the quarter, I do want to spend a minute talking about what we've been going through here in New York City over the past several days. We have contingency plans for almost all occurrences, and last Friday, as we began to receive dire warnings, we implemented our emergency management procedures, coordinating all of our personnel to have round-the-clock coverage in all of our buildings. Our engineers, quarters, security guards and property management professionals all hunkered down during the storm. Some of them still today in buildings, which are dark, literally living in the buildings, sleeping and shifts on cots. I'm enormously proud of our team for securing all of our buildings during the storm and for communicating on a realtime basis updates to all of our tenants. Most of our buildings did not lose power and have remained throughout. Other than 1 small building directly in 1 of the flood zones downtown, which will take about a week to bring, all of the buildings that lost power should be up and running as soon as completes the repairs to its network, which we hope will take place this weekend.
Now let me turn to the quarter. While the overall market in New York is tepid, we've had a strong quarter. We released over 500,000 square feet of office space in the third quarter, which took our office occupancy up 50 basis points to 95.8%. 
The highlights of our leasing activity this quarter are 2 headquarters consolidation deals, 1 in financial services and 1 in advertising. 
At 350 Park, we leased 103,000 square feet to M&T Bank in a renewal and expansion transaction, which allowed M&T to consolidate its Wilmington Trust Division, which they'd recently acquired into 350 Park Avenue. To produce the expansion space in this complicated deal, we terminated 2 leases early and also renegotiated 2 other leases. 
At 909 3rd Avenue, we leased 220,000 square feet to IPG, the Interpublic Group, which allowed IPG to consolidate offices from 4 different locations into our building. For IPG, we created a headquarters environment, including dedicated lobby space and elevators, branding and a great outdoor terrace space. 
To make this deal, we leveraged our existing relationship with IPG, which is also our lead tenant at 100 West 33rd Street, where IPG occupies over 400,000 square feet. 
These 2 large transactions, plus another 22 leases signed in the quarter, had an average starting rent of $58.74 per square foot, with a positive mark-to-market of 8.9% cash and 5% GAAP. 
Many of the flash analyst reports, which I read last night, commented on our CapEx. Our average GIs were elevated this quarter at $56.92 per square foot. That's because 75% of this quarter's leasing activity was new and expansion deals versus 30%, which was the case in the first half of the year. 
Our year-to-date office leasing activity is a robust 1.5 million square feet, which includes some 620,000 square feet of leasing and our 10 Plaza office portfolio. The Midtown South submarket with its type availabilities has been expanding to include 10 Plaza. In fact, 10 Plaza recently was reported to have the lowest Class A vacancy rate in Midtown at sub 5%. This has allowed us to begin to push Pent Plaza and at 1 Penn Plaza, we recently have completed several deals over $60 per square foot. 
For our entire 19.6 million square foot office portfolio, we have a relatively modest amount of upcoming lease expirations with 156,000 square feet expiring in the balance of this year and 673,000 square feet expiring in '13. This amount of upcoming expirations has been substantially reduced as a result of our aggressive forward leasing over the last several quarters. 
Let me now spend a minute talking about some market dynamics. Since last summer, the market effectively has been at equilibrium with the Manhattan vacancy rate hovering just under 10%. Our occupancy at 95.8% continues to outperform the market as we do quarter in and quarter out. Renewals this year have made the bulk of the transactions in the market enabling tenants to avoid capital expenditures. In fact, in Midtown there have only been 3 major relocation deals year-to-date over 100,000 square feet, the IPG lease I mentioned earlier is one of those 3 deals. Uncertainty in the regulatory environment has also led the financial institutions to remain on the sidelines. However, our diversified portfolio of over 1,200 tenants is not reliant on any 1 industry. Take a look at the list of the major tenants in our New York segment property table in the financial supplement and you'll see what I mean.
In years past, view space in the tower of the building was the first ago. With affordability being the theme of today, that trend seems to have reversed somewhat as tenants are focusing on the base of buildings both for the value prospect and the flexibility larger floor plates provide for open space planning. This bodes well for the releasing of the former Citibank space at 666 Fifth Avenue. While you likely have read that Citi has moved out of the space, we will continue to receive rent through the lease expiration 2 years hence, giving us considerable time to release the space. 
Regarding trophy space, which includes our buildings at 645th Avenue, 8887 Avenue, 280 Park Avenue and 350 Park Avenue, while the market is not yet back to the premium seen before the financial crisis, there have been 27 transaction over $100 per square foot year-to-date. I'm pleased to say that 3 of those $100-plus deals have been in our own portfolio and we have 2 more in the hopper. 
We have a long track record of transforming buildings to create value, having done it time and again, 770 Broadway, 1740 Broadway 645 Avenue and 8887 Avenue just to name a few. Earlier this year, we completed the total redevelopment of our 330 Madison property, capped by over 400,000 square feet of leasing activity, including headquarters transactions with Guggenheim Partners and Jones Lang LaSalle. 
At 280 Park Avenue, the transformation is now underway with our joint venture partner, SL Green. Designed by, Cohen Patterson Fox, the building will feature a new double height lobby spanning the entire Park Avenue block front and a Winter Garden interconnecting both building surrounded by new plazas. The receptivity to the overall redevelopment plan from the brokerage and tenant communities have been very positive, and while we are fielding lease increase, our experience in the many buildings we have redeveloped is that while the renderings are great, what the tenant community and brokers really appreciate is the quality of the redevelopment when they start to see it completed. 
We have 1 other major transformation well underway at 1290 Avenue of the Americas where we are dramatically upgrading the scaling character of the lobby, storefront and elevators to match the stature of this 2 plus million square foot corporate headquarters building. This project is currently under construction with completion scheduled in the first quarter of 2013. The change already is dramatic. I'd encourage you to go take a look. 
Turning now to our Manhattan street retail portfolio where we own the dominant 2.3 million-square-foot retail platform. We lease 180,000 square feet of retail space year-to-date with positive mark-to-market of 19.4% cash and 27.2% GAAP. 
The retail market is very strong, driven by the continued growth in tourism, which is expected to reach 52 million visitors this year. New York continues to be the gateway market for global retailers including, for example, Massimo Dutti, one of Zara's brands, which opened its first store in the United States at our 689 Fifth Avenue property last month. Retail rents are now well above their all-time highs, approaching $3,000 per square foot on 5th Avenue and $2,000 per square foot in Times Square. 
In Times Square, last week, Microsoft opened a pop-up stores at our 1540 Broadway property for the global launch of its new surface tablet computers. Sales here have exceeded Microsoft's expectations, which again demonstrates the strength of the Times Square market, both Massimo Dutti and Microsoft deals speak to the exceptional quality of our Manhattan street retail portfolio. We continue to have great growth prospects in this portfolio of extremely well-located assets with in-place rents averaging 30% under market and by the way many individual assets are multiples of that. We couldn't be more excited about the prospects for the development of the full block front of retail signage at Marriott Marquis, which is directly across from 1540 Broadway, the 2 best sites by far in Times Square. 
For the entire year New York division, which is a total of 25.5 million square feet, we had a good quarter with positive same-store of 0.7% cash and 0.3% GAAP. If you exclude the Hotel Penn, which was weak this quarter, along with the rest of the New York hotel market, the same-store increase is positive 1.9% cash and 1.3% GAAP. Now let me turn it back over to Mike.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Let me turn it over to Mitchell Schear now to discuss our Washington business.
componenttext: Thanks, David. Let me turn it over to Mitchell Schear now to discuss our Washington business.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning to everybody. While we in Washington largely dodged Sandy, I have an incredibly competent team on the ground that was fully prepared for the worst. Our colleagues in New York before the brunt of it and really did job during
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning to everybody. While we in Washington largely dodged Sandy, I have an incredibly competent team on the ground that was fully prepared for the worst. Our colleagues in New York before the brunt of it and really did job during this crisis. As you may know, our Washington portfolio is approximately 20 million square feet, concentrated in Washington D.C. and Arlington, Virginia directly across the Potomac River in Crystal City, Pentagon City and Roslyn. Our footprint is about twice the size of any of our peers. 
I want to start by contextualizing the Washington Metro market in general. Currently, market demand is soft but not as soft as many believe. Our tenants await the election results and clarity on the budget crisis. There is leasing activity in the market. In 2012, the gross leasing activity is expected to be about 32 million square feet, which is actually on par with the 15-year average. There is a lot of churn but not yet enough absorption to eat into vacancies, especially in this peak year. Through 3 quarters of this year, there was negative absorption of about 2.5 million square feet in the market. Rents are holding steady but concessions are up to attract tenants. Limited supply over the next several years will help to stabilize the market, but we don't really expect the market to gain significant traction until 2014. 
Within our Washington portfolio, our year-to-date leasing velocity has been brisk. Over 1.6 million square feet so far, well ahead of our projection for the full year. We are attracting good activity and consistently executing more than our fair share of deals at good risks. 
In fact, we had signed 6 new leases each, one of them over 50,000 square feet as compared to 1 new lease over 25,000 square feet in all of 2011. In the third quarter specifically, we leased 435,000 square feet at very good average initial rents of $44.02 per square foot, and this is versus 389,000 square feet leased in the same quarter last year. The GAAP mark-to-market was 13.8%, and the cash mark-to-market was 8.9%. Of the total 435,000 square feet pleased this quarter, government leases accounted for 170,000 square feet and the private sector leased 265,000 square feet. So despite a slow leasing environment in Washington, we continue to win business. 
To start off the fourth quarter, we just executed a lease for 108,000 square feet to the Corporate Executive Board in one of our buildings that is about to be renovated in Roslyn. With this lease, we have now resolved 871,000 square feet or roughly 36% of the 2.4 million square feet of Department of Defense lease expirations resulting from Brack. This includes our plan to demolish the existing 350,000 square foot 1851 South Bell building to rebuild a new state of the art 700,000 square foot office tower at 1900 Crystal Drive. We received final full approvals from Arlington County for this project in September. Almost all of the Brack relocations have now taken place, and we are looking ahead. 
In our 20 million-square-foot portfolio, lease expirations in 2013 are below our average with a very manageable 940,000 square feet expiring. Releasing the remainder of the Brack space is a function of time, and we will emerge stronger when complete. We had a similar experience in 2004 and 2005 when the Patent and Trademark Office relocated, but in the end, we benefited by releasing to a more diverse population of tenants and by increasing rents by over 30%. We are confident the same will be true this time, too. 
For the entire Washington DC division, same-store EBITDA for the quarter was down 6.9% on a GAAP basis and 9.2% on a cash basis due to Brack. Overall occupancy is 84%. Our residential portfolio, which consists of 2,424 units in Arlington and D.C. representing about approximately 12% of the business is over 97% occupied and had a quarterly same-store EBITDA increase of 8.5%. And finally, we are delighted to welcome Nike to Georgetown with the opening last weak of their new flagship 31,000 square foot store at our 3040 M Street property. Now I'd like to turn it back over to Mike. Thank you.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mitchell. I wanted to cover a few things of retail and talk a minute about sustainability. Our retail strips and mall team continue to perform. In the quarter, we had an 8.8% GAAP mark-to-market and occupancy was 93.4%. While the shakeouts in supe
componenttext:
Thanks, Mitchell. I wanted to cover a few things of retail and talk a minute about sustainability. Our retail strips and mall team continue to perform. In the quarter, we had an 8.8% GAAP mark-to-market and occupancy was 93.4%. While the shakeouts in supermarket industry and the closings and downsizings associated with Best Buy and others are a concern, this nationwide trend is lest important to us because of the concentration of assets we have in the densely populated, high barrier to entry, tri-state area. Our segment is much smaller and leaner now and the numbers show it. Occupancy is up 11.6% to 94.2% as a result of the Motorola Mobility lease and EBITDA improved by $1.1 million to $13.7 million. The commitment of Motorola Mobility Google at the merchandise is having a positive ripple effect we thought it would have. We also benefited from restocking the showroom tenants in the building in a very efficient way. Let's stock sustainability for a minute. We've been working very hard on this front. Our commitment to sustainability is highlighted in our annual sustainability report available on our website and reprinted in this letter. We think sustainability is not only good business, it's morally partly responsible our profits in the end. Most recently, we are proud to have rank #1 of our entire industry and we were 87th of our America's 500 largest publicly traded companies and 500 largest companies internationally. That's quite an achievement. By the end of 2012, we will have LEED-certified over 30 million feet in our portfolio, more than any other single owner nationwide. We are a leader in energy management and submetering and our efforts have resulted and significant reduction and energy consumption throughout our portfolio.
In summary, we are very excited about the future of our great assets and businesses, which are run by a very talented management team. We will continue to make Vornado a simpler company, improving the portfolio and recycled capital and increase asset quality. I'd like to turn it over to Joe Mac now for the financial review.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Yesterday, we reported comparable funds from operations of $1.14 per share versus $1.13 per share in the prior year's third quarter. Total funds from operations was $1.34 per share versus $1.05 per share in the prior year's third quart
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Yesterday, we reported comparable funds from operations of $1.14 per share versus $1.13 per share in the prior year's third quarter. Total funds from operations was $1.34 per share versus $1.05 per share in the prior year's third quarter. First Call was $1.17 per share as some analysts factor in noncomparable items into their estimates and others do not. 
Our noncomparable items in this quarter consisted of a $19.7 million after-tax gain on the sale of the Canadian Trade Shows, $12.5 million of FFO from discontinued operations, a $11.7 million gain on redemption of preferred units, $4.3 million of income from the mark-to-market of the JC Penney derivative position, partially offset by a $7 million impairment in other costs. 
As Mike indicated, we announced the sale of Green Acres Mall for $500 million to the Macy's Company. Net proceeds from the sale will be $185 million after repaying the existing loan and closing costs. The gain for financial statement purposes will be approximately $195 million. The tax gain will be approximately $304 million and is expected to be deferred as part of a exchange. The Green acres sale is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2013 and is conditioned on the closing of the Kings Plaza. 
Alexander's, our 32.4% owned affiliate, also announced the sale of Kings Plaza Mall for $751 million to Net proceeds to Alexander's from the sale will be $481 million after repaying at the existing loan in closing. Alexander's gain for financial statement purposes will be approximately $603 million, of which Vornado's 32.4% share will be approximately $181 million, after adjusting for certain acquisition cost in Alexander's stock. Alexander's tax gain will be approximately $625 million, which is expected to be paid out shareholders as a special long-term capital gains dividend this year. Vornado's share of the dividend is approximately $202 million or $1.02 per Vornado share and is also expected to paid out this year to Vornado shareholders as a special long-term capital gain dividend. The Kings Plaza sale is expected to be completed this quarter. 
We have over $2.7 billion of liquidity at September 30. Our consolidated debt-to-enterprise value was 36.8% and our consolidated debt to EBITDA is 6.6x. 
In capital market transactions this quarter, we issued $300 million of 5.7% preferred shares and redeemed $255 million of preferred shares and preferred units, with a weighted average dividend cost of 6.9%. This results in $3.1 million lower annual dividend cost for rus and the $11.7 million gain and noncomparable items I just mentioned. We refinanced 2 properties for aggregate proceeds of $248 million with a weighted average term of 10 years, which resulted in $49 million of net proceeds. The weighted average interest rate of the new loans is 3.3% compared to 2.3% weighted average interest rate on the maturing loans. That is a result going from floating rate to fixed rates on one of those loans in the amount of $150 million. Now the new loan has a 12-year term fixed rate. 
We also unencumbered 2 properties by repaying $151 million outstanding balance on the mortgage loans, which added a weighted average interest rate of 5.4%, of course the source of that was our over net cash balances, which earned 0. 
Importantly, we expect to complete the refinancing of 1290 Avenue of the Americas in the fourth quarter in a single asset CMBS for close to $1 billion, replacing the $409 million mortgage that now exists on the property and with a much lower interest rate. We also expect our financing acquisition of 666 Fifth Avenue retail with a $390 million mortgage. We are highly confident that the $721 million of remaining 2013 maturities will be refinanced at favorable rates as well. At this time, I'd like to turn it over for Q&A.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think, George, we're going to continue to sell assets as we move into 2013. There's still considerable assets that we want to sell, and we will sell over a period of time. I don't want to specify in which assets are going to be handled, but I think we'l
componenttext: I think, George, we're going to continue to sell assets as we move into 2013. There's still considerable assets that we want to sell, and we will sell over a period of time. I don't want to specify in which assets are going to be handled, but I think we'll continue to do in a very measured and orderly way. And we will then look at each asset as we did in the case-to-case distributed that money is Green Acres were doing the right kind exchange on this tax and basis how to handle that. The acquisition market is a competitive market. We only are going to buy assets that what we think we get very good long-term rate of return on a adjusted basis that meets our hurdle rates. It's a process which I think we did a very good job so far. We're going to continue to do that, and as we do that, we'll obviously update you on the specifics in the quarter calls and obviously filings. I will say this that we do have a great effort that every asset that we sell obviously improve the quality of the portfolio, granting that we would buy. So that is one of the recycling themes that we will continue to emphasize.

componenttextpreview: David will take a shot at that one. I think generally, what we're seeing in the market is basic equilibrium. The expectation is that the actual availability/vacancy rate downtown, as some of the new product the World Trade Center and some of the buildin
componenttext:
David will take a shot at that one. 
I think generally, what we're seeing in the market is basic equilibrium. The expectation is that the actual availability/vacancy rate downtown, as some of the new product the World Trade Center and some of the buildings where tenants will be relocating downtown to Midtown now we're going to be seeing some much higher vacancy rates downtown. I think generally though, what we're seeing still to date is continuing job growth in New York. Year-to-date, we've had about 30,000, 40,000 number, I think the number is about 43,000 office sector jobs, actually met yesterday with one of the brokerage houses and their kind of Chief Economists and the projections for 2013 are considering job growth with actually acceleration as we get into 2014, 2015. So I think next year is going to be relatively flat I think as we get out to '14 and '15, I feel better about some growth in rents.

componenttext: This is Steve, everybody's looking at me for that answer. First of all, we remain committed to the investment that JCPenney will report their quarter a week from today next Friday. Management is executing a plan of enormous change on that business from a enormous change this year, which is the transition year it's a difficult year. It's actually no secret that is proving out to be more difficult than the management team thought. The second year recycles. It begins in 90 days on February 1, 2013. We remain committed to the investment. We believe that the transformation and the creation of a unique retailer and what Rod Johnson calls "a specialty department store" has a prospects of being enormously successful. This is a tough period. We understand that, but we remain committed to the investment.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think the 3 markets where we've really seen some significant growth in rents over the last year plus are on 5th Avenue and 5th Avenue effectively is 2 segments from about 51st Street North and South 51st to 42nd Street, Madison Avenue and then Times Squ
componenttext: I think the 3 markets where we've really seen some significant growth in rents over the last year plus are on 5th Avenue and 5th Avenue effectively is 2 segments from about 51st Street North and South 51st to 42nd Street, Madison Avenue and then Times Square of course. We've probably seen the single largest increase in rents on 5th Avenue in the quarter from 42nd 251 Street, seeing rents over the last year approximately double to a tad in excess of that. As I said earlier on upper Fifth Avenue, we've really seen rents approaching $3,000 a foot and that was in fact validated with the deal that we did with Mac earlier this year and again on Madison Avenue, we've seen extraordinary strength in the market. We have closed a number of deals at 11 East 68 Street, again at rents at and above $1,000 a foot. I think as you look at some of the sales numbers, I think the comment I'll make is Times Square is an extraordinary market because it's almost a 24/7 market. As we look at some of our retailers, some of them have approached sales per square foot of $6,000, $7,000 and $8,000 a foot on some small stores. So I don't things are just "advertisements and branding." I think companies today and especially a number of the fast retailers got to do their own production, these stores really are making money for them.

But you want the space to be decide by multiple people so you can existing tenant beds occupied that.

componenttext: It's actually Andrew, and I cannot hear that. What Steve said was that the 5.2% was calculated based upon the existing cash flow. If it was a market by the first digit would have been a 4 maybe even a 3 with a high second digit. So we have a capital lease for $240 million. We have a capital lease liability for the same amount on the balance sheet. The income statement won't have any effect until it gets out of development, and that's about the summary.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I want to just comment, I know you guys focused on the going and yields of any of these deals, and it's not unimportant but it isn't how we look at things. We look at the overall return we could create over a period of time and sometimes we're biting belo
componenttext: I want to just comment, I know you guys focused on the going and yields of any of these deals, and it's not unimportant but it isn't how we look at things. We look at the overall return we could create over a period of time and sometimes we're biting below market leases to justify a much lower cap rate that we could turn in a period of years into a much higher yield. So the 5.2% doesn't really relate to the overall cost of capital is really where the asset and generate over a period of time. So whether it's the Marriott deal, we look at that over a period of holding period, which would be as low as 5 to 10 years for longer and then that has to be clear that hurdle of our cost of capital.

componenttextpreview: You know I'm not going to speculate. We're going to sell assets, and if we found a great acquisitions we would have to proceed with those. We've been focusing on the core markets that we're in. We're are focusing on the street retail in New York, as David
componenttext: You know I'm not going to speculate. We're going to sell assets, and if we found a great acquisitions we would have to proceed with those. We've been focusing on the core markets that we're in. We're are focusing on the street retail in New York, as David mentioned before, particularly for value-added opportunities on releasing down the road and redevelopment down the road. That's a good example of that is a process to go through adding additional space, really working that asset over a period of time to try to create, as Joe mentioned, the 5.2% existing income going substantially up. So street retail and New York with value-added components is particularly a focus, we are looking at the lack of office buildings. I think there's an escalating volume of office deals coming to the market as we go into the fourth quarter and into next year, bigger deals that might provide some opportunity. Obviously, if there's a lease rollover in some of those that will take place down the road at the effect of this the price could affect the potential so in D.C. we haven't seen much distress and asset sales despite negatively viewed market. We obviously been the net seller in D.C. and we look at all these markets to try a find deal that's in our parameters so I would say the acquisition market is not easier to find deals right now that meet that criteria because there's more money in more demand for it than I think the deals volume right now suggest so we'll continue to look at it and whether it will be in that seller or not will continue to sell remains to be seen.

componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Vornado Realty Trust Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Call. My name is Christine, and I will be your operator for today's call. This call is being recorded for replay purposes. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Ms. Cathy Creswell, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to Vornado Realty Trust Third Quarter Earnings Call. Yesterday afternoon, we issued our third quarter earnings release and filed our Form 10-Q with the Securities and Exchange Commission. These documents, as well as our supplemental fin
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to Vornado Realty Trust Third Quarter Earnings Call. Yesterday afternoon, we issued our third quarter earnings release and filed our Form 10-Q with the Securities and Exchange Commission. These documents, as well as our supplemental financial information package, are available on our website, www.vno.com, under the Investor Relations section. In these documents and during today’s call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliation of these measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in our earnings release, Form 10-Q and financial supplements. 
Please be aware that statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements and actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. 
Please refer to our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K for more information regarding these risks and uncertainties. The call may include time sensitive information that may be accurate only as of today’s date. The Company does not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements.
On the call today from management for our opening comments are: Michael Fascitelli, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Greenbaum, President of the New York Division; Mitchell Schear, President of the Washington, D.C. Division; and Joseph Macnow, Chief Financial Officer. 
In addition, Steven Roth, Chairman of the Board, will be present for the duration of the call. I will now turn the call over to Michael Fascitelli.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cathy. Good morning, and welcome to our Third Quarter Earnings Call. We are happy you are all be joining us today and appreciate your time and attention. After my opening remarks, David Greenbaum will talk about our New York business, and Mitchell
componenttext:
Thanks, Cathy. Good morning, and welcome to our Third Quarter Earnings Call. We are happy you are all be joining us today and appreciate your time and attention. After my opening remarks, David Greenbaum will talk about our New York business, and Mitchell Schear will talk about our Washington business, followed by Joe Macnow, who will provide a financial overview of the quarter and then we'll answer your questions. We'll end at 11:00.
Before getting started, I would like to acknowledge the devastation the Northeast suffered from Hurricane Sandy. This tragedy, which cost over 100 lives, thus far, and tens of billions of property damage, affected our home bases in New York and Washington, particularly New York, which was hardest. 
I'm pleased to report that we suffered no personal injuries and only minor property damage. I want to thank all of our people for the incredible job they did and express our best wishes to all those affected by the hurricane as they recover. 
David and Mitchell will comment further, particularly David, on  specifics for their businesses. 
Overall, I'm quite satisfied with our third quarter results, which were a penny better than last year's third quarter. In spite of the downward pressure coming from BRAC in Washington, D.C., an old story. It's interesting to note that if Washington would have been level this year to last, we would have had comparable FFO performance over the prior year's quarter of 7%. 
The Washington office market is sluggish, and the New York office market, lacking support from the financial service industry, is locked in neutral. However, it is clear from our financial results that our New York portfolio is outperforming the market, and our Washington portfolio is outperforming the projections we provided in our public filings. David and Mitchell will expand on this in a few minutes. Let me update you on asset sales. Part of our program to simplify and to recycle capital into our core portfolio of high-quality office and retail assets. 
In the third quarter, we closed on the previously announced sales of the Washington Design Center, Washington Office Center, the Canadian Trade Show business in Dorchester, a non-core strip shopping center, total proceeds from these sales were $323 million, with a  third quarter net gain of $149 million. 
Importantly, in the fourth quarter, we announced the sale of 2 malls for $1.25 billion, the Green Acres Mall and Alexander's King Plaza Mall, which were both sold to the Macerich Company. When completed, these transactions will produce substantial proceeds and gains, and Joe will provide further detail in a few minutes on the specifics of these gains and distributions. 
We also announced the sale of Reston Executive, a 3-building suburban office complex in Fairfax County, Virginia for $126 million, resulting in a net gain of $35 million. We sold the building on Market Street in Philadelphia, which is part of The Gallery at Market East for $60 million, resulting in a gain of $35 million. We expect to close both these deals in the fourth quarter. 
In addition, we expect to close in the fourth quarter the previously announced sale of the Boston Design Center for approximately $72 million. 
Lastly, we sold our equity investment and [indiscernible] to Brookfield Asset Management for $28 million. We will continue to hold $25 million of [indiscernible] 4.75% 2018 debentures. 
In summary, this year, we produced $2.3 billion of assets sales with a net gain of $674 million and expect to pay at least a special long-term capital gain dividend of $202 million or $1.02 per share for Vornado's share of King's Plaza. 
We intend to do a tax-deferred like-kind exchange with the sale proceeds of Green Acres and others. We will continue to dispose of non-core assets. We just acquired a 25% participation in a $475 million first mortgage and mezzanine loan on 710 Seventh Avenue, a retail redevelopment property in Times Square, where we already have 2 dominant properties in that market. 
The yield today is 11%, which will increase our [indiscernible senior position. We will continue to invest in our existing assets and development opportunities. Given the current environment, our strategy for acquisition will be measured and focused on continuing to expand our leading New York City street retail platform and upgrading our high-quality office property platform. 
Let me now turn the call over to David to discuss the New York business.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael, and good morning to all. Before I turn to the results for the quarter, I do want to spend a minute talking about what we've been going through here in New York City over the past several days. We have contingency plans for almost all o
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael, and good morning to all. Before I turn to the results for the quarter, I do want to spend a minute talking about what we've been going through here in New York City over the past several days. We have contingency plans for almost all occurrences, and last Friday, as we began to receive dire warnings, we implemented our emergency management procedures, coordinating all of our personnel to have round-the-clock coverage in all of our buildings. Our engineers, quarters, security guards and property management professionals all were hunkered down during the storm. Some of them still today in buildings which are dark, literally living in the buildings, sleeping in shifts on cots. 
I'm enormously proud of our team for securing all of our buildings during the storm and for communicating, on a realtime basis, updates to all of our tenants. Most of our buildings did not lose power and have remained open throughout. Other than one small building directly in one of the flood zones downtown, which will take about a week to bring back, all of the buildings that lost power should be up and running as soon as Con Edison completes the repairs to its network, which we hope will take place this weekend.
Now let me turn to the quarter. While the overall market in New York is tepid, we've had a strong quarter. We leased over 500,000 square feet of office space in the third quarter, which took our office occupancy up 50 basis points to 95.8%. 
The highlights of our leasing activity this quarter are 2 headquarters consolidation deals, one in financial services and one in advertising. 
At 350 Park, we leased 103,000 square feet to M&T Bank in a renewal and expansion transaction, which allowed M&T to consolidate its Wilmington Trust division, which it recently acquired into 350 Park Avenue. To produce the expansion space [indiscernible] to you in this complicated deal, we terminated 2 leases early and also renegotiated 2 other leases. 
At 909 3rd Avenue, we leased 220,000 square feet to IPG, the Interpublic Group, which allowed IPG to consolidate offices from 4 different locations into our building. For IPG, we created a headquarters environment, including dedicated lobby space and elevators, branding and a great outdoor terrace space. 
To make this deal, we leveraged our existing relationship with IPG, which is also our lead tenant at 100 West 33rd Street, where IPG occupies over 400,000 square feet. 
These 2 large transactions, plus another 22 leases signed in the quarter, had an average starting rent of $58.74 per square foot, with a positive mark-to-market of 8.9% cash and 5% GAAP. 
Many of the flash analyst reports, which I read last night, commented on our CapEx. Our average TIs were elevated this quarter at $56.92 per square foot. That's because 75% of this quarter's leasing activity was new and expansion deals versus 30%, which was the case in the first half of the year. 
Our year-to-date office leasing activity is a robust 1.5 million square feet, which includes some 620,000 square feet of leasing in our Penn Plaza office portfolio. The Midtown South submarket, with its tight availability, has been expanding to include Penn Plaza. In fact, Penn Plaza recently was reported to have the lowest Class A vacancy rate in Midtown at sub 5%. This has allowed us to begin to push Penn Plaza office rents and at One Penn Plaza, we recently have completed several deals over $60 per square foot. 
For our entire 19.6 million square foot office portfolio, we have a relatively modest amount of upcoming lease expirations with 156,000 square feet expiring in the balance of this year and 673,000 square feet expiring in '13. This amount of upcoming expirations has been substantially reduced as a result of our aggressive forward leasing over the last several quarters. 
Let me now spend a minute talking about some market dynamics. Since last summer, the market effectively has been at equilibrium with the Manhattan vacancy rate hovering just under 10%. Our occupancy at 95.8% continues to outperform the market, as we do quarter in and quarter out. Renewals this year have made up the bulk of the transactions in the market enabling tenants to avoid capital expenditures. In fact, in Midtown there have only been 3 major relocation deals year-to-date over 100,000 square feet, the IPG lease, I mentioned earlier, is one of those 3 deals. 
Uncertainty in the regulatory environment has also led the financial institutions to remain on the sidelines. However, our diversified portfolio of over 1,200 tenants is not reliant on any one industry. Take a look at the list of the major tenants in our New York segment property table in the financial supplement and you'll see what I mean.
In years past, view space in the tower of the building was the first to go. With affordability being the theme of today, that trend seems to have reversed somewhat as tenants are focusing on the base of buildings both for the value prospect and the flexibility larger floor plates provide for open space planning. This bodes well for the re-leasing of the former Citibank space at 666 Fifth Avenue. While you likely have read that Citi has moved out of the space, we will continue to receive rent through the lease expiration 2 years hence, giving us considerable time to re-lease the space. 
Regarding trophy space, which includes our buildings at 6 45th Avenue, 888 Seventh Avenue, 280 Park Avenue and 350 Park Avenue, while the market is not yet back to the premium seen before the financial crisis, there have been 27 transactions over $100 per square foot year-to-date. I'm pleased to say that 3 of those $100-plus deals have been in our own portfolio and we have 2 more in the hopper. 
We have a long track record of transforming buildings to create value, having done it time and again, 770 Broadway, 1740 Broadway, 6 45th Avenue and 888 Seventh Avenue just to name a few. Earlier this year, we completed the total redevelopment of our 330 Madison property, capped by over 400,000 square feet of leasing activity, including headquarters transactions with Guggenheim Partners and Jones Lang LaSalle. 
At 280 Park Avenue, the transformation is now underway with our joint venture partner, SL Green. Designed by Kohn Pedersen Fox, the building will feature a new double height lobby, spanning the entire Park Avenue block front, and a winter garden interconnecting both buildings surrounded by new plazas. The receptivity to the overall redevelopment plan from the brokerage and tenant communities has been very positive. And while we are fielding lease inquiries, our experience in the many buildings we have redeveloped is that, while the renderings are great, what the tenant community and brokers really appreciate is the quality of the redevelopment when they start to see it completed. 
We have one other major transformation well underway at 1290 Avenue of the Americas where we are dramatically upgrading the scaling character of the lobby, storefront and elevators to match the stature of this 2 plus million square foot corporate headquarters building. This project is currently under construction with completion scheduled for the first quarter of 2013. The change already is dramatic. I'd encourage you to go take a look. 
Turning now to our Manhattan street retail portfolio where we own the dominant 2.3 million-square-foot retail platform. We leased 180,000 square feet of retail space year-to-date with positive mark-to-markets of 19.4% cash and 27.2% GAAP. 
The retail market is very strong, driven by the continued growth in tourism, which is expected to reach 52 million visitors this year. New York continues to be the gateway market for global retailers including, for example, Massimo Dutti, one of Zara's brands, which opened its first store in the United States at our 689 Fifth Avenue property last month. Retail rents are now well above their all-time highs, approaching $3,000 per square foot on 5th Avenue and $2,000 per square foot in Times Square. 
In Times Square, last week, Microsoft opened a pop-up store at our 1540 Broadway property for the global launch of its new surface tablet computers. Sales here have exceeded Microsoft's expectations, which again demonstrates the strength of the Times Square market. Both Massimo Dutti and Microsoft deals speak to the exceptional quality of our Manhattan street retail portfolio. We continue to have great growth prospects in this portfolio of extremely well-located assets with in-place rents averaging 30% under market and, by the way, many individual assets are multiples of that. We couldn't be more excited about the prospects for the development of the full block front of retail signage at Marriott Marquis, which is directly across from 1540 Broadway, the 2 best sites, by far, in Times Square. 
For the entire year New York division, which is a total of 25.5 million square feet, we had a good quarter with positive same-store of 0.7% cash and 0.3% GAAP. If you exclude the Hotel Penn, which was weak this quarter, along with the rest of the New York hotel market, the same-store increase is positive 1.9% cash and 1.3% GAAP. Now let me turn it back over to Mike.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning to everybody. While we, in Washington, largely dodged Sandy, I have an incredibly competent team on the ground that was fully prepared for the worst. Our colleagues in New York bore the brunt of it and really did a yeoman's
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning to everybody. While we, in Washington, largely dodged Sandy, I have an incredibly competent team on the ground that was fully prepared for the worst. Our colleagues in New York bore the brunt of it and really did a yeoman's job during this crisis. As you may know, our Washington portfolio is approximately 20 million square feet, concentrated in Washington, D.C. and Arlington, Virginia directly across the Potomac River in Crystal City, Pentagon City and Rosslyn. Our footprint is about twice the size of any of our peers. 
I want to start by contextualizing the Washington Metro market, in general. Currently, market demand is soft, but not as soft as many believe, as tenants await election results and clarity on the budget crisis. There is leasing activity in the market. In 2012, the gross leasing activity is expected to be about 32 million square feet, which is actually on par with the 15-year average. There is a lot of churn but not yet enough absorption to eat into vacancies, especially in this peak BRAC year. Through 3 quarters of this year, there was negative absorption of about 2.5 million square feet in the market. Rents are holding steady but concessions are up to attract tenants. Limited supply over the next several years will help to stabilize the market, but we don't really expect the market to gain significant traction until 2014. 
Within our Washington portfolio, our year-to-date leasing velocity has been brisk. Over 1.6 million square feet so far, well ahead of our projection for the full year. We are attracting good activity and consistently executing more than our fair share of deals at good risks. 
In fact, we have signed 6 new leases, each one of them over 50,000 square feet as compared to one new lease over 25,000 square feet in all of 2011. In the third quarter, specifically, we leased 435,000 square feet at very good average initial rents of $44.02 per square foot, and this is versus 389,000 square feet leased in the same quarter last year. The GAAP mark-to-market was 13.8%, and the cash mark-to-market was 8.9%. Of the total 435,000 square feet leased this quarter, government leases accounted for 170,000 square feet and the private sector leased 265,000 square feet. So despite a slow leasing environment in Washington, we continue to win business. 
To start off the fourth quarter, we just executed a lease for 108,000 square feet to the Corporate Executive Board in one of our buildings that is about to be renovated in  Rosslyn. With this lease, we have now resolved 871,000 square feet, or roughly 36%, of the 2.4 million square feet of Department of Defense lease expirations resulting from BRAC. This includes our plan to demolish the existing 350,000 square foot 1851 South Bell building to rebuild a new state-of-the-art 700,000 square foot office tower at 1900 Crystal Drive. We received final, full approvals from Arlington County for this project in September. Almost all of the BRAC relocations have now taken place and we are looking ahead. 
In our 20 million-square-foot portfolio, lease expirations in 2013 are below our average, with a very manageable 940,000 square feet expiring. Re-leasing the remainder of the BRAC space is a function of time and we will emerge stronger when complete. We had a similar experience in 2004 and 2005 when the Patent and Trademark Office relocated, but in the end, we benefited by re-leasing to a more diverse population of tenants and by increasing rents by over 30%. We are confident the same will be true this time, too. 
For the entire Washington DC division, same-store EBITDA for the quarter was down 6.9% on a GAAP basis and 9.2% on a cash basis due to BRAC. Overall occupancy is 84%. 
Our residential portfolio, which consists of 2,424 units in Arlington and D.C., representing about approximately 12% of the business, is over 97% occupied and had a quarterly same-store EBITDA increase of 8.5%. And finally, we are delighted to welcome Nike to Georgetown with the opening last weak of their new flagship 31,000 square foot store at our 3040 M Street property. Now I'd like to turn it back over to Mike. Thank you.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mitchell. I want to cover a few things at retail, non-New York City retail mart, and talk a minute about sustainability. Our retail strips and mall team continue to perform. In the quarter, we had an 8.8% GAAP mark-to-market and occupancy was 93.4
componenttext:
Thanks, Mitchell. I want to cover a few things at retail, non-New York City retail mart, and talk a minute about sustainability. Our retail strips and mall team continue to perform. In the quarter, we had an 8.8% GAAP mark-to-market and occupancy was 93.4%. While the shakeouts in supermarket industry, in the closings and downsizings, associated with Best Buy and others, are a concern, this nationwide trend is less important to us because of the concentration of assets we have in the densely populated, high barrier to entry, affluent tri-state area. Our Mart segment is much smaller and leaner now and the numbers show it. Occupancy is up 11.6% to 94.2% as a result of the Motorola Mobility-Google lease and EBITDA improved by $1.1 million to $13.7 million. The commitment of Motorola Mobility-Google at the merchandise mart is having the positive ripple effect we thought it would have. We also benefited from restacking the showroom tenants in the building in a very efficient way. 
Let's talk sustainability for a minute. We've been working very hard on this front. Our commitment to sustainability is highlighted in our annual sustainability report available on our website and reprinted in Steve's chairman letter. We think sustainability is not only good business and it's morally responsible and works our increase our profits in the end. Most recently, we are proud to have ranked #1 in Newsworks' green rankings of our entire industry, and we were 87th of our America's 500 largest publicly-traded companies and 500 largest companies internationally. That's quite an achievement. 
By the end of 2012, we will have LEED-certified over 30 million feet in our portfolio, more than any other single owner nationwide. We are a leader in energy management and sub-metering, and our efforts have resulted in significant reduction in  energy consumption throughout our portfolio.
In summary, we are very excited about the future of our great assets and businesses, which are run by a very talented management team. We will continue to make Vornado a simpler company, improving the portfolio and recycle capital and increase asset quality. I'd like to turn it over to Joe Mac now for the financial review.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Yesterday, we reported comparable funds from operations of $1.14 per share versus $1.13 per share in the prior year's third quarter. Total funds from operations was $1.34 per share versus $1.05 per share in the prior year's third quart
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Yesterday, we reported comparable funds from operations of $1.14 per share versus $1.13 per share in the prior year's third quarter. Total funds from operations was $1.34 per share versus $1.05 per share in the prior year's third quarter. First Call was $1.17 per share as some analysts factor in noncomparable items into their estimates and others do not. 
Our noncomparable items in this quarter consisted of a $19.7 million after-tax gain on the sale of the Canadian Trade Shows, $12.5 million of FFO from discontinued operations and $11.7 million gain on redemption of preferred units, $4.3 million of income from the mark-to-market of the JC Penney derivative position, partially offset by a $7 million Verde impairment and other costs. 
As Mike indicated, we announced the sale of Green Acres Mall for $500 million to the Macerich Company. Net proceeds from the sale will be $185 million after repaying the existing loan and closing costs. The gain for financial statement purposes will be approximately $195 million. The tax gain will be approximately $304 million and is expected to be deferred as part of a like-kind exchange. The Green Acres sale is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2013 and is conditioned on the closing of the King's Plaza Mall. 
Alexander's, our 32.4% owned affiliate, also announced the sale of King's Plaza Mall for $751 million to Macerich. Net proceeds to Alexander's from this sale will be $481 million after repaying at the existing loan in closing costs. Alexander's gain, for financial statement purposes, will be approximately $603 million, of which Vornado's 32.4% share will be approximately $181 million, after adjusting for certain acquisition cost in Alexander's stock. Alexander's tax gain will be approximately $625 million, which is expected to be paid out to shareholders as a special long-term capital gain dividend this year. Vornado's share of the dividend is approximately $202 million or $1.02 per Vornado share and is also expected to paid out this year to Vornado shareholders as a special long-term capital gain dividend. The King's Plaza sale is expected to be completed this quarter. 
We have over $2.7 billion of liquidity at September 30. Our consolidated debt-to-enterprise value was 36.8% and our consolidated debt to EBITDA is 6.6x. 
In capital market transactions this quarter, we issued $300 million of 5.7% preferred shares and redeemed $255 million of preferred shares and preferred units, with a weighted average dividend cost of 6.9%. This results in $3.1 million lower annual dividend cost to us and the $11.7 million gain in noncomparable items I just mentioned. 
We refinanced 2 properties for aggregate proceeds of $248 million with a weighted average term of 10 years, which resulted in $49 million of net proceeds. The weighted average interest rate of the new loans is 3.3% compared to 2.3% weighted average interest rate on the maturing loans. That's as a result of going from floating rate to fixed rate on one of those loans in the amount of $150 million. Now the new loan has a 12-year term, fixed rate. 
We also unencumbered 2 properties by repaying $151 million outstanding balance on the mortgage loans, which added a weighted average interest rate of 5.4%. Of course, the source of that was our overnight cash balances, which earned 0. 
Importantly, we expect to complete the refinancing of 1290 Avenue of the Americas in the fourth quarter in a single asset CMBS for close to $1 billion, replacing the $409 million mortgage that now exists on the property and with a much lower interest rate. We also expect our financing acquisition of 656 Fifth Avenue retail with a $390 million mortgage. We are highly confident that the $721 million of remaining 2013 maturities will be refinanced at favorable rates as well. At this time, I'd like to turn it over for Q&A.

componenttext: As I said earlier, I think that our expectations for 2013 are relatively modest, and we expect to see traction in the marketplace starting in 2014. So I would say that we're looking at a couple year period once we get into 2014 to really regain -- closer to our stabilized occupancy.

componenttextpreview: And Mike, you had a successful year selling assets in 2012. I guess, thinking about 2013, how do you see the pipeline of sales? How should we think about the level of potential proceeds? And what would you put at the top of the list of your wish-to-sell l
componenttext: And Mike, you had a successful year selling assets in 2012. I guess, thinking about 2013, how do you see the pipeline of sales? How should we think about the level of potential proceeds? And what would you put at the top of the list of your wish-to-sell list?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think, George, we're going to continue to sell assets as we move into 2013. There's still considerable assets that we want to sell, and we will sell over a period of time. I don't want to specify exactly the order in which assets are going to be handled
componenttext: I think, George, we're going to continue to sell assets as we move into 2013. There's still considerable assets that we want to sell, and we will sell over a period of time. I don't want to specify exactly the order in which assets are going to be handled, but I think we'll continue to do it in a very measured and orderly way. And we will then look at each asset, as we did in the case of King's Plaza, we distributed that money. Here in Green Acres were doing the like-kind exchange depending on its tax and its basis of how to handle that. The acquisition market is a competitive market. We only are going to buy assets there where we think we get very good long-term rate of return on a adjusted basis that meets our hurdle rates. It' a process which I think we did a very good job so far. We're going to continue to do that. And as we do that, we'll obviously update you on the specifics in the quarterly calls and, obviously, in our filings. I will say this, that we do have a great effort that every asset that we sell obviously improve the quality of the portfolio, granting that we would buy. So that is one of the recycling themes that we will continue to emphasize.

componenttext: I'll take it you like the execution on that, by that question, so thank you. I think that we have The Plant still in the market for sale, and obviously, we have to sell other assets right behind that, that are coming to the market, for totaling approximately $400 million to $500 million. And we'll continue to do that as we go through the fourth quarter and obviously into next year. These deals won't close in the fourth quarter, of course. So and then, each asset, just like we sold the asset [indiscernible] which was not core, and we will continue to sell assets here and there that we think don't fit the geographies, that don't fit the profile, what we want to go forward with. So it's a process that we will generate a considerable amount of further proceeds from, but I don't, Michael, I think as we go through those are the 2 most immediate ones that we have on the market.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Obviously, since I initiated the idea several years ago and reiterated in a second letter, we think it's a good idea. We think it's an extremely important -- just to focus for a moment on Park Avenue which, I guess, we in New York consider to be the #1 co
componenttext: Obviously, since I initiated the idea several years ago and reiterated in a second letter, we think it's a good idea. We think it's an extremely important -- just to focus for a moment on Park Avenue which, I guess, we in New York consider to be the #1 corporate thoroughfare in the world, actually. That it have the kind of economic incentives that developers need to tear down obsolete buildings and build new buildings. So we're very -- actually, we're very pleased that the powers-that-be are working on it. The Bloomberg administration is in its twilight years, they're trying to rush a plan through and we hope they succeed. And we think it will be good for New York.

componenttext: Last quarter, you said New York City rents were rising modestly and so, I was just wondering, if financial services kind of stays in this a bit of a rested state, do you think there's the risk that, as lower Manhattan product comes online next year, we can take a step backwards? headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think, generally, what we're seeing in the market is basic equilibrium. The expectation is that the actual availability/vacancy rate downtown, as some of the new product, the World Trade Center and some of the buildings where tenants will be relocating
componenttext: I think, generally, what we're seeing in the market is basic equilibrium. The expectation is that the actual availability/vacancy rate downtown, as some of the new product, the World Trade Center and some of the buildings where tenants will be relocating downtown to Midtown, that we're going to be seeing some much higher vacancy rates downtown. I think generally, though, what we're seeing still to date is continuing job growth in New York. Year-to-date, we've had about 30,000, 40,000, I think the number is about 43,000 office sector jobs, actually met yesterday with one of the brokerage houses and their, kind of, chief economist, and the projections for 2013 are continuing job growth with, actually, acceleration as we get into 2014, 2015. So I think next year is going to be relatively flat, I think, as we get out to '14 and '15, I feel better about some growth in rents.

componenttext: Okay just another question, maybe this is for Joe. As you guys pay a special here, sell some retail, which generally tends to have less CapEx than say, office. headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Fortunately, some of that asset disposition, lack of FFO and taxable income going forward, is offset by growth in our other businesses. So the Board tries to get the dividend to be somewhere close to recurring taxable income, and I think that will continu
componenttext: Fortunately, some of that asset disposition, lack of FFO and taxable income going forward, is offset by growth in our other businesses. So the Board tries to get the dividend to be somewhere close to recurring taxable income, and I think that will continue. And I don't think there's much upward pressure on tax volume in 2013 but there's certainly no downward pressure on it either.

componenttextpreview: This is Steve, everybody's looking at me for that answer. So Jamie, first of all, we remain committed to the investment. JCPenney will report their quarter, a week from today, next Friday. Management is executing a plan of enormous change on that business
componenttext: This is Steve, everybody's looking at me for that answer. So Jamie, first of all, we remain committed to the investment. JCPenney will report their quarter, a week from today, next Friday. Management is executing a plan of enormous change on that business, enormous change. This year, which is the transition year, is a difficult year. It's actually no secret that is proving out to be more difficult than the management team thought. The second year recycles, it begins in 90 days on February 1, 2013. We remain committed to the investment. We believe that the transformation of the -- and the creation of a unique retailer, and what Rod Johnson calls "a specialty department store", has the prospects of being enormously successful. This is a tough period. We understand that, but we remain committed to the investment.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could revisit the retail. You mentioned rents, I think are at peak levels. Can you talk about that dynamic a bit? How have they trended over the past year or 2? And to what extent has that been driven by the strength in retail sales? And
componenttext: I was hoping you could revisit the retail. You mentioned rents, I think are at peak levels. Can you talk about that dynamic a bit? How have they trended over the past year or 2? And to what extent has that been driven by the strength in retail sales? And to extend, is that a desire by retailers to have a flagship store and accept a higher occupancy cost? Do you think the rents can continue to experience kind of outsized growth?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think the 3 markets where we've really seen some significant growth in rents over the last year plus are on 5th Avenue, and 5th Avenue effectively really is 2 segments, from about 51st Street North and South 51st to 42nd Street; Madison Avenue and then
componenttext: I think the 3 markets where we've really seen some significant growth in rents over the last year plus are on 5th Avenue, and 5th Avenue effectively really is 2 segments, from about 51st Street North and South 51st to 42nd Street; Madison Avenue and then Times Square of course. We've probably seen the single largest increase in rents on 5th Avenue in the corridor from 42nd to 51st Street, seeing rents effectively over the last year approximately double to a tad in excess of that. As I said earlier, on upper Fifth Avenue, we've really seen rents approaching $3,000 a foot and that was in fact validated with the deal that we did at 689 5th Avenue with Mac earlier this year. And again on Madison Avenue, we've seen extraordinary strengths in the market. We have closed a number of deals at 11 East 68th Street, again, at rents at and above $1,000 a foot. I think as you look at some of the sales numbers, I goes the comment I'll make is, Times Square is an extraordinary market because it's almost a 24/7 market. As we looked at some of our retailers, some of them have approached sales per square foot of $6,000, $7,000 and $8,000 a foot on some small stores. So I don't think these things are just "advertisements and branding." I think companies today, and especially a number of the fast retailers that to do their own production, these stores really are making money for them.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll would just comment also, the seller always had a pretty good run at rents also. And if you look at retail, as David said in his comments, we have great, well-located assets with a lot of rollover that will produce substantial mark-to-market gains. An
componenttext: I'll would just comment also, the seller always had a pretty good run at rents also. And if you look at retail, as David said in his comments, we have great, well-located assets with a lot of rollover that will produce substantial mark-to-market gains. And even if there's a pause in these rents at this level,  at this level it's going to enormous mark-to-market and demand for these assets are worldwide from the tenants that David mentioned. And also the shoppers are worldwide, in terms of tourism around the world, as well as tourism within the United States, so we expect these markets to be very good long-term. They won't be straight line up. There may be a pause as the market absorbs these new rental levels, but then you see more tenants trying to drive that. So bullish, we're very bullish on this over the long-term

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012

componenttext: And a follow-up is on that mark-to-market. So as you look at some of the renewables, expirations you get over the next few years, to what extent do you expect the tenants to renew in-place and to what extent you think you need to rebuild out this space?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: It varies by case, you know. I think 6 45th Avenue, which H&M was their original flagship store would have gone up substantially, multiples. They chose to relocate a cheaper site and start an increase of existing ramp but not the size of that. And we'll b
componenttext: It varies by case, you know. I think 6 45th Avenue, which H&M was their original flagship store would have gone up substantially, multiples. They chose to relocate a cheaper site and start an increase of existing ramp but not the size of that. And we'll back fill that space with tenants that will generate substantial multiples to what they were paying. But it's case-by-case. Some tenants will be new. Some will downsize and renew. Some tenants will seek more value-oriented locations. But it's hard to make a generalization. But you want the space to be desired by multiple people so you can push the rent even the existing tenant would chose or might coming in to occupied that.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012

componenttext: The only thing, it's David, I might add to that is, at 640 with H&M having announced their relocation, it actually is a great opportunity for us. That lease comes up in 2015. We're out there now marketing the space. We expect, actually, if we want we can get our hands on it, probably some time around middle of next year.
